awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Process Monitoring and Diagnosis Software for Decarbonizing Industrial Distillation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve the energy efficiency and carbon footprint of distillation facilities to facilitate decarbonization in chemical and refining industries, the top two energy use processing industries consuming almost half of the U.S. manufacturing sector’s primary energy and emitting half of its greenhouse gases. By de-risking distillation system operation at its optimal operating region, this software tool is expected to reduce energy requirement and greenhouse gas emissions. Some of the well-known industrial processes that benefit from this software tool include crude oil fractionation, natural gas separation, amine regeneration from carbon dioxide capture, air separation, liquors production, etc. Furthermore, by reducing operating costs, improving production throughput, and reducing safety risks, this software tool enhances the economic competitiveness of U.S. chemical plants and refineries, and improves health, safety, and environmental wellness of nearby communities. The commercialization of this software will also help train the next-generation workforce in chemical and refining industries, including plant operators, process engineers, and plant managers, to use digital tools for plant data analytics.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a data analytics technology for real-time process monitoring and fault diagnosis of industrial distillation systems. By strategically learning from historical operating data, this software tool enables online monitoring of multiple nonparametric, heterogeneous process data streams continuously produced from sensors, as well as accurate fault classification from various possible fault scenarios. This is accomplished by holistic integration of online process monitoring and fault diagnosis in a new hierarchical architecture. Compared to existing general purpose process monitoring tools that attempt to accomplish both tasks altogether, this hierarchical architecture offers superior fault detection and diagnosis performance in terms of fault detection speed, fault classification accuracy, and robustness to handle multiple plant operation scenarios. This smart distillation monitoring software can also be seamlessly integrated with existing plant control and supervisory systems already in place, which is favorable for retrofitting purposes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps award provided the framework and training to understand the potential applications, customers, and key value propositions of a new fault detection framework for industrial distillation processes for energy-efficient chemical separation applications.

Effective process monitoring and fault detection are critically important to ensure the safety, productivity, and sustainability of chemical manufacturing sectors, including chemical, petrochemical, refining, pharmaceutical, and agrochemical industries. Nowadays, distillation systems in modern chemical plants and refineries are continuously monitored by numerous sensors. Despite having access to large volumes of historical and online sensor data, chemical plants still face several challenges in effectively utilizing them to perform fast, accurate, and robust fault detection and diagnosis in real-time. This is because existing process monitoring software solutions are not capable of handling complex fault scenarios and online sensor measurements. Instead, chemical plants and refineries rely heavily on plant operator's experience to detect and raise alarms, which often causes faults to be noticed long after they have occurred.

This project focused on the commercialization potential of a novel online distillation monitoring software that holistically integrates fault detection and fault diagnosis in a hierarchical framework. By developing advanced computational techniques and algorithms based on statistical process control and deep learning, this software allows chemical plants and refineries to detect any distillation process anomaly as soon as possible while maintaining a user-specified false alarm rate. It is expected that our distillation monitoring software will help de-risk industrial distillation operation and enable safe distillation operation at the designed optimal operating window, which can improve energy efficiency and production throughput of distillation units by 5-15%.

The major goals of this NSF I-Corps project were to participate in an immersive, experiential learning process about innovation and learn how to find product market fit. Initially, we focused primarily on distillation equipment manufacturers and plant control system licensors as our potential customers. We conducted more than 100 interviews with potential customers, which included plant managers, technical leads, and sales managers in plant control system licensors, as well as distillation experts in distillation technology licensors. After spending time listening carefully to the customers' needs and experiences, we realized that there is an excellent fit for our product in chemical plants and manufacturing sites. In particular, plant managers and technical directors in medium- and large-size chemical and refining companies are our potential customers. On the other hand, process and control engineers and plant operators are the end users of our distillation monitoring software. We have also identified strategies to get, keep, and grow customer relationships. We could leverage tradeshows, professional conferences, and industrial connections to obtain new customers. To keep the customers, we could develop online and in-person training modules to enhance user stickiness. We could also provide excellent software maintenance and technical support to keep the customers. To grow the customers, we could introduce new features and modules to the software package and upsell them to customers with tiered subscription feeds. We have identified several sources of revenue streams, including software licensing subscription, maintenance, and support service fees.

As a result of the learnings from I-Corps, the team successfully secured research and development funding from Oklahoma's OCAST program to continue the development and commercialization efforts of our distillation monitoring software. We have been working closely with an industrial collaborator to test and validate the effectiveness of our algorithm using actual plant data.
